title: Ho–Lee model
text:
In <a href="financial%20mathematics">financial mathematics</a>, the Ho–Lee model is a <a href="short-rate%20model">short-rate model</a> widely used in the pricing of <a href="bond%20option">bond option</a>s, <a href="swaptions">swaptions</a> and other <a href="interest%20rate%20derivatives">interest rate derivatives</a>, and in modeling future <a href="interest%20rate">interest rate</a>s. It was developed in 1986 by Thomas Ho and Sang Bin Lee.
Under this model, the short rate follows a <a href="gaussian">normal process</a>:
The model can be calibrated to market data by implying the form of formula_2 from market prices, meaning that it can exactly return the price of bonds comprising the <a href="yield%20curve">yield curve</a>. This calibration, and subsequent valuation of <a href="bond%20option">bond option</a>s, <a href="swaption">swaption</a>s and other <a href="interest%20rate%20derivative">interest rate derivative</a>s, is typically performed via a <a href="Binomial%20options%20pricing%20model">binomial</a> <a href="Lattice%20model%20%28finance%29">lattice based model</a>. <a href="Closed-form%20expression">Closed form</a> valuations of <a href="bond%20%28finance%29">bonds</a>, and "<a href="Black%20model">Black-like</a>" bond option formulae are also available.
As the model generates a symmetric ("bell shaped") distribution of rates in the future, negative rates are possible. Further, it does not incorporate <a href="mean%20reversion%20%28finance%29">mean reversion</a>. For both of these reasons, models such as <a href="Black%E2%80%93Derman%E2%80%93Toy%20model">Black–Derman–Toy</a> (<a href="lognormal">lognormal</a> and mean reverting) and <a href="Hull%E2%80%93White%20model">Hull–White</a> (mean reverting with lognormal variant available) are often preferred. The <a href="Kalotay%E2%80%93Williams%E2%80%93Fabozzi%20model">Kalotay–Williams–Fabozzi model</a> is a <a href="lognormal">lognormal</a> analogue to the Ho–Lee model, although is less widely used than the latter two.
